places.name: Djinguereber Mosque
places.description: Built in 1327 by order of Mansa Musa, this mosque is a prime example of Sudano-Sahelian architecture and one of the oldest in continuous use in Africa.

places.name: Sankoré University and Mosque
places.description: Part of the historic Sankoré Madrasah, it was once a major center of Islamic scholarship, attracting scholars from across the Islamic world.

places.name: Sidi Yahya Mosque
places.description: Completed in 1440, this mosque is known for its spiritual significance and is part of Timbuktu’s historic Islamic education institutions.

places.name: Ahmed Baba Institute
places.description: A center dedicated to preserving thousands of ancient manuscripts that reflect the city’s scholarly past.

places.name: Timbuktu Manuscripts
places.description: Collections housed in various libraries and private collections across the city, featuring works on astronomy, law, medicine, and theology.

places.name: Tomb of Askia Mohamed
places.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site connected to the Songhai Empire and its Islamic leadership, highlighting the region’s historical ties.

places.name: Timbuktu Museum
places.description: A small but informative museum with artifacts and exhibits about the city’s history, culture, and manuscripts.

places.name: House of Explorer René Caillié
places.description: The home where the French explorer stayed when he became the first European to visit Timbuktu and return alive in 1828.
